abstract_summ: The relationship between online search traffic and confirmed case numbers was examined.The 7-day follow-up with prospectively collected data showed no significant correlations of the observed data with the predicted daily new cases or daily deaths, using search interest of COVID, COVID heart, and COVID pneumonia.Methods We performed a Google TrendsTM search for “Coronavirus” and compared Relative Search Volumes (RSV) indices to the number of reported COVID-19 cases by the European Center for Disease Control (ECDC) using time-lag correlation analysis.Moreover, high to moderate correlations between Google relative search volumes (RSVs) and COVID-19 cases were found in Taipei (lag-3), New Taipei (lag-2), Taoyuan (lag-2), Tainan (lag-1), Taichung (lag0), and Kaohsiung (lag0).The daily new cases peaked at 35,098 cases on April 10, 2020 and the daily deaths peaked at 2,494 on April 15, 2020.
title_summ: Based ModelApplications of Google Search Trends for risk communication in infectious disease management: A case study of the COVID-19 outbreak in TaiwanAssociation of the COVID-19 pandemic with Internet Search Volumes: A Google TrendsTM AnalysisOnline behavioural patterns for Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in the United KingdomThe use of google trends to investigate the loss of smell related searches during COVID‐19 outbreakPredicting COVID-19 Incidence Using Anosmia and Other COVID-19 Symptomatology: Preliminary Analysis Using Google and TwitterAssessing the community risk perception toward COVID-19 outbreak in South Korea: evidence from Google and NAVER relative search volumeTrends and Prediction in Daily New Cases and Deaths of COVID-19 in the United States:The use of Google trends for acral symptoms during COVID-19 outbreak in France.Assessment of the impact of media coverage in coronavirus-related Google Trends: Infodemiology study.An Internet Search-Interest
title_abstract_phrases: CONCLUSIONS: Search terms related to COVID-19 are highly correlated with the COVID-19 daily new cases and deaths in the USA.Applications of Google Search Trends for risk communication in infectious disease management: A case study of the COVID-19 outbreak in TaiwanOBJECTIVE: An emerging outbreak of a novel coronavirus, COVID-19, has now been detected in at least 211 countries worldwide.The relationship between online search traffic and confirmed case numbers was examined.CLINICALTRIALAssessing the community risk perception toward COVID-19 outbreak in South Korea: evidence from Google and NAVER relative search volumeThis study aimed to explore the patterns of community health risk perception of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in South Korea using Internet search data.All rights reservedPredicting COVID-19 Incidence Using Anosmia and Other COVID-19 Symptomatology: Preliminary Analysis Using Google and TwitterOBJECTIVE: To determine the relative correlations of Twitter and Google Search user trends concerning smell loss with daily coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) incidence in the United States, compared to other severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) symptoms.Methods We performed a Google TrendsTM search for “Coronavirus” and compared Relative Search Volumes (RSV) indices to the number of reported COVID-19 cases by the European Center for Disease Control (ECDC) using time-lag correlation analysis.
